private_information: I have direct observation of blocks A B C D E F G and their initial relations
I can move one top block at a time and I know standard BlocksWorld move constraints
worker_a.goal: Help determine the final arrangement of all blocks after executing the given action sequence and report observations to the orchestrator

private_information: I have direct observation of blocks H I J K L M and their initial relations
I can move one top block at a time and I know standard BlocksWorld move constraints
worker_b.goal: Help determine the final arrangement of all blocks after executing the given action sequence and report observations to the orchestrator

private_information: I coordinate multiple agent observations and produce a consolidated PDDL domain and problem suitable for FastDownwards
orchestrator.goal: Integrate inputs from the other agents and produce a final PDDL domain and problem that captures the BlocksWorld instance and the target goal for FastDownwards

rules: Only the top block of a stack can be moved
Only one block can be carried at a time
Standard BlocksWorld move primitives are allowed: unstack, stack, pickup, putdown

public_information: This is a BlocksWorld instance with labeled blocks A through M
Initial arrangement: A is on F, B is on H, C is on D, D is on E, E is on the table, F is on L, G is on the table, H is on I, I is on the table, J is on the table, K is on M, L is on J, M is on G
The agents will execute a concrete sequence of 50 actions in the given order using BlocksWorld primitives
Only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time
The action sequence is an authoritative record of the moves to be applied to the initial state

analysis.system_prompt: You are an agent observing and reasoning about a subset of the BlocksWorld instance. Provide precise observations, identify which blocks you see and their initial relations, and enumerate any top-of-stack constraints or local consequences you deduce from the given action sequence. Do not emit PDDL. Produce a concise structured observation and a partial step-by-step rationale for the orchestrator.
analysis.prompt: Your name is worker_a. You are in an environment with the following public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private information: {agents->worker_a->private_information} Your role is to analyze and report observations and a local interpretation of the action sequence. Provide a structured observation summary and a short list of possible ambiguities for the orchestrator to resolve.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an agent observing and reasoning about a subset of the BlocksWorld instance. Provide precise observations, identify which blocks you see and their initial relations, and enumerate any top-of-stack constraints or local consequences you deduce from the given action sequence. Do not emit PDDL. Produce a concise structured observation and a partial step-by-step rationale for the orchestrator.
analysis.prompt: Your name is worker_b. You are in an environment with the following public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private information: {agents->worker_b->private_information} Your role is to analyze and report observations and a local interpretation of the action sequence. Provide a structured observation summary and a short list of possible ambiguities for the orchestrator to resolve.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent BlocksWorld modeling and PDDL suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Integrate observations from other agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode the initial state and the intended final goal derived from the action sequence. Keep agent actions distinct where needed and ensure compatibility with FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive structured observations from two agents about a BlocksWorld instance. Use the public information {environment->public_information} and the agents' observations {obs_worker_a} and {obs_worker_b}. Your task is to build a valid PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeting FastDownwards that represent the initial state from the provided initial_on data and the goal state implied by executing the provided action sequence in order. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure that multiple-agent action distinctions are preserved if relevant, and make no unsupported assumptions beyond what the observations and public information provide. If you detect ambiguities, document them explicitly in a short note preceding the PDDL, then produce the PDDL encoding you judge best.
